title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 1 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ecclesiastes chapter 1 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 1 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ecclesiastes Chapter 1.

questions.question: Who is identified as the author of the words in Ecclesiastes 1:1?
options: The Preacher, the son of David
Moses
King Solomon
The prophet Isaiah
questions.correctAnswer: The Preacher, the son of David
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:1 states that the words are of the Preacher, the son of David, king in Jerusalem.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 1:2, how does the Preacher describe everything under the sun?
options: Vanity of vanities
Full of joy
Everlasting
A great blessing
questions.correctAnswer: Vanity of vanities
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:2 says, 'Vanity of vanities; all is vanity,' as declared by the Preacher.

questions.question: What question about human labor is asked in Ecclesiastes 1:3?
options: What profit hath a man of all his labour which he taketh under the sun?
How long shall man toil without rest?
Who remembers the works of a man?
Why do men work so hard?
questions.correctAnswer: What profit hath a man of all his labour which he taketh under the sun?
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:3 specifically asks what profit a man gains from all his labor under the sun.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 1:4 say happens to generations and the earth?
options: One generation passes and another comes, but the earth remains forever.
Generations live and die, and the earth also perishes.
Generations remain the same, and the earth changes daily.
The earth passes away with each generation.
questions.correctAnswer: One generation passes and another comes, but the earth remains forever.
questions.explanation: Verse 4 explains that generations come and go, but the earth abides forever.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 1:5, what does the sun do?
options: Arises, goes down, and hastens to where it arose
Stays still in the sky
Rises once and never sets
Moves slowly across the sky
questions.correctAnswer: Arises, goes down, and hastens to where it arose
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:5 describes the sun rising, setting, and hastening back to its place of rising.

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 1:6 says the wind moves in one direction only.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 6 states the wind goes toward the south, then turns to the north, continually whirling and returning according to its circuits.

questions.question: What natural cycle involving rivers and the sea is described in Ecclesiastes 1:7?
options: All the rivers run into the sea, yet the sea is not full; the rivers return again to their source.
Rivers dry up before reaching the sea.
The sea overflows into the rivers.
Rivers never meet the sea.
questions.correctAnswer: All the rivers run into the sea, yet the sea is not full; the rivers return again to their source.
questions.explanation: Verse 7 explains that rivers flow into the sea but the sea is never full, and water returns to where the rivers begin.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 1:8, what is the condition of the eye and ear?
options: The eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing.
The eye and ear are fully content.
Only the eye is satisfied, but not the ear.
Both eye and ear are always pleased.
questions.correctAnswer: The eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing.
questions.explanation: Verse 8 declares that the eye and ear have no satisfaction in what they perceive.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 1:9 say about new things under the sun?
options: There is no new thing under the sun.
Many new things appear every day.
New things are created by God daily.
The sun creates new things.
questions.correctAnswer: There is no new thing under the sun.
questions.explanation: Verse 9 states that what has been done will be done again; nothing new exists under the sun.

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 1:10 suggests that new things can be said to be truly new.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 10 clarifies that even things considered new have existed before us in old times.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 1:11 say about the remembrance of former things?
options: There is no remembrance of former things; neither will there be remembrance of things to come.
Former things are always remembered.
Only great events are remembered.
Remembrance of former things lasts forever.
questions.correctAnswer: There is no remembrance of former things; neither will there be remembrance of things to come.
questions.explanation: Verse 11 states there is no remembrance of former things, nor will future things be remembered by those after us.

questions.question: Who was the Preacher according to Ecclesiastes 1:12?
options: King over Israel in Jerusalem
A prophet
A priest
A scribe
questions.correctAnswer: King over Israel in Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Verse 12 identifies the Preacher as king over Israel in Jerusalem.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Ecclesiastes 1:13: 'And I gave my heart to seek and search out by ______ concerning all things that are done under heaven.'
options: wisdom
strength
faith
patience
questions.correctAnswer: wisdom
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:13 says the Preacher sought and searched out by wisdom concerning all things done under heaven.

questions.question: What conclusion does the Preacher reach about all works under the sun in Ecclesiastes 1:14?
options: All is vanity and vexation of spirit.
All is good and fruitful.
All is eternal and blessed.
All is joyful and rewarding.
questions.correctAnswer: All is vanity and vexation of spirit.
questions.explanation: Verse 14 states that after seeing all works done under the sun, the Preacher finds all to be vanity and vexation of spirit.

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 1:18 states that increasing knowledge decreases sorrow.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 18 explains that with much wisdom comes much grief, and increasing knowledge increases sorrow.

medium.title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 1 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ecclesiastes Chapter 1 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with finding lasting satisfaction in their work. Based on Ecclesiastes 1, what biblical truth would you share about labor and its rewards?
options: All labor under the sun is ultimately vanity and does not bring lasting profit
Hard work always leads to great wealth and satisfaction
Only work done in the church is valuable
Labor brings endless joy and fulfillment
questions.correctAnswer: All labor under the sun is ultimately vanity and does not bring lasting profit
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:3, 1:14, and 1:8 show that all labor under the sun is vanity and vexation of spirit, indicating that worldly work alone cannot bring lasting satisfaction.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 1 teach us about humility in the pursuit of wisdom?
options: Increasing wisdom leads to increased sorrow and grief
Wisdom guarantees happiness and peace
One should avoid gaining knowledge to stay joyful
Wisdom makes a person proud and self-sufficient
questions.correctAnswer: Increasing wisdom leads to increased sorrow and grief
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:18 states that with much wisdom comes much grief, teaching humility and that knowledge reveals life’s complexities and trials.

questions.question: A believer feels discouraged because they see no lasting change in the world. According to Ecclesiastes 1, what biblical perspective can encourage their perseverance?
options: Generations come and go, but the earth remains forever
Everything changes rapidly and unpredictably
Human efforts always bring permanent change
Only miracles bring lasting change
questions.correctAnswer: Generations come and go, but the earth remains forever
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:4 explains the cyclical nature of generations passing away while the earth endures, encouraging perseverance through trials.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 1 guide believers in maintaining contentment despite life's repetitive nature?
options: Recognizing there is nothing new under the sun helps us accept life’s rhythms
Always seek the newest experiences to be content
Discontentment is the natural Christian state
Comparison to others will bring contentment
questions.correctAnswer: Recognizing there is nothing new under the sun helps us accept life’s rhythms
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:9-10 teach that nothing is truly new, which helps believers find contentment by understanding life’s repetitive cycles.

questions.question: A believer struggles with frustration over unanswered prayers and seemingly fruitless efforts. What biblical truth from Ecclesiastes 1 can help them trust God’s sovereign plan?
options: God has given mankind the task to labor under the sun as a form of exercise
Unanswered prayers mean God is absent
Efforts without immediate results are useless
Only spiritual work counts, not physical labor
questions.correctAnswer: God has given mankind the task to labor under the sun as a form of exercise
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:13 explains that God has given mankind the burden of labor under heaven as an exercise, encouraging trust in God’s purpose behind toil.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 1, what attitude should believers adopt about the pursuit of knowledge?
options: Pursuing knowledge brings sorrow and should be approached with humility
Knowledge is always a source of joy and peace
It is better not to seek knowledge to avoid grief
Knowledge makes one wiser than God
questions.correctAnswer: Pursuing knowledge brings sorrow and should be approached with humility
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:17-18 teaches that seeking wisdom includes understanding folly and that increased knowledge is accompanied by increased sorrow.

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 1 teaches that the cycles of nature, such as the sun rising and setting, symbolize God’s unchanging faithfulness.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:5-7 describes natural cycles like the sun and rivers, illustrating the consistent order God maintains, symbolizing His faithfulness.

questions.question: True or False: The Preacher claims in Ecclesiastes 1 that there is truly something new under the sun that mankind has never experienced before.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:9-10 clearly states there is no new thing under the sun; all that exists has been done before.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 1 encourage believers to approach their work ethic and daily labor?
options: Work diligently but with an understanding that earthly labor is limited in ultimate significance
Avoid work since it is vanity
Only work that visibly benefits others is worthwhile
Work is only a means to gain wealth and status
questions.correctAnswer: Work diligently but with an understanding that earthly labor is limited in ultimate significance
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:3 and 1:14 reveal that while work is laborious and often vanity, recognizing this calls for humility and diligence without misplaced trust in results.

questions.question: A believer is feeling overwhelmed by the world’s challenges and wonders if their efforts matter. What does Ecclesiastes 1 teach about the endurance of the earth versus human generations?
options: The earth remains forever while generations come and go
Human generations are eternal
The earth is temporary like human life
Only spiritual life endures, not physical creation
questions.correctAnswer: The earth remains forever while generations come and go
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:4 contrasts the passing of generations with the enduring earth, reminding believers of God’s sustaining creation amid human transience.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 1 suggest about human senses and their satisfaction?
options: The eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing
The senses can be fully satisfied by worldly pleasures
Hearing and seeing always bring contentment
Senses are irrelevant to spiritual life
questions.correctAnswer: The eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:8 expresses the insatiable nature of human senses, teaching believers to seek deeper satisfaction beyond physical experience.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Ecclesiastes 1:15, "That which is crooked cannot be made _______; and that which is wanting cannot be numbered."
options: straight
perfect
whole
new
questions.correctAnswer: straight
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:15 uses the metaphor of crooked things not being made straight to illustrate limitations and imperfections in life.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 1 instruct believers regarding the remembrance of past and future generations?
options: There is no remembrance of former things nor of things that are to come
All past deeds are always remembered
Future generations will know everything that happened before
Memory is the key to spiritual growth
questions.correctAnswer: There is no remembrance of former things nor of things that are to come
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:11 teaches that human memory is limited and that both past and future are often forgotten, encouraging believers to focus on God’s eternal perspective.

questions.question: What does the Preacher say about his wisdom compared to those before him in Jerusalem, and how should believers apply this humility today?
options: He had more wisdom and experience but recognized its limitations
He was the wisest without any doubt
He rejected the wisdom of his predecessors
He did not seek wisdom at all
questions.correctAnswer: He had more wisdom and experience but recognized its limitations
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:16-17 show that despite great wisdom, the Preacher found it vexation of spirit, teaching believers humility in knowledge and continual dependence on God.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 1 encourage believers to view the natural world’s cycles in relation to God’s order?
options: The cycles of sun, wind, and rivers illustrate God’s consistent order
Nature is chaotic and unpredictable
Natural cycles have no spiritual meaning
God changes the order of nature frequently
questions.correctAnswer: The cycles of sun, wind, and rivers illustrate God’s consistent order
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:5-7 describes natural cycles that continually repeat, demonstrating God’s sustaining and unchanging order in creation.

hard.title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 1 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ecclesiastes Chapter 1.

questions.question: What is the repeated phrase that introduces the theme of futility in Ecclesiastes 1?
options: Vanity of vanities
Fear of the Lord
Blessed be the Lord
Grace abounds
questions.correctAnswer: Vanity of vanities
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:2 begins with 'Vanity of vanities; all is vanity,' emphasizing the theme of life's futility.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 1, what does the Preacher question regarding human labor?
options: What profit hath a man of all his labour which he taketh under the sun?
How shall a man inherit eternal life?
Who shall separate us from the love of Christ?
What is the beginning of wisdom?
questions.correctAnswer: What profit hath a man of all his labour which he taketh under the sun?
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:3 questions the value or profit of human labor under the sun, expressing existential doubt.

questions.question: Which of the following natural cycles is NOT mentioned in Ecclesiastes 1 as an example of repetitive motion?
options: The sun rising and setting
The wind turning from south to north
The moon changing phases
Rivers running into the sea
questions.correctAnswer: The moon changing phases
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:5-7 mentions the sun, the wind, and rivers but does not mention the moon's phases.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'The eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with ______.'
options: hearing
singing
prayer
wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: hearing
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:8 uses parallelism to express human insatiability: 'The eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing.'

questions.question: What literary theme is emphasized by the phrase 'there is no new thing under the sun'?
options: Cyclical nature of history and human experience
The promise of new revelation
The uniqueness of Israel's covenant
The finality of judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Cyclical nature of history and human experience
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:9 highlights the repetitive and cyclical nature of events, reinforcing the theme of futility and repetition.

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 1 states that the earth abides forever despite generations passing away.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:4 contrasts the passing of generations with the earth's enduring permanence.

questions.question: In Ecclesiastes 1, what role does the Preacher claim for himself in verse 1 and verse 12?
options: King over Israel in Jerusalem
Prophet of the Most High
High Priest of Israel
Scribe of the Law
questions.correctAnswer: King over Israel in Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Verses 1 and 12 identify the Preacher as 'the son of David, king in Jerusalem,' underscoring his authoritative voice.

questions.question: Which phrase best describes the Preacher's emotional response to wisdom and knowledge in Ecclesiastes 1?
options: Much wisdom is much grief
Wisdom is a shield
Knowledge brings joy
Folly is the beginning of wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Much wisdom is much grief
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:18 states, 'For in much wisdom is much grief: and he that increaseth knowledge increaseth sorrow,' revealing the emotional cost of wisdom.

questions.question: What does the Preacher mean by 'That which is crooked cannot be made straight' in verse 15?
options: Some things are inherently flawed and cannot be corrected
All sins can be forgiven
Lawlessness will be punished
The righteous will always be blessed
questions.correctAnswer: Some things are inherently flawed and cannot be corrected
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:15 uses a metaphor indicating the limits of human ability to fix certain problems or injustices.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 1:13 describe the work God has given to mankind?
options: A sore travail to seek and search out by wisdom
An easy task to enjoy life
A command to build the temple
A covenant to obey the law
questions.correctAnswer: A sore travail to seek and search out by wisdom
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:13 describes the human experience of struggling to understand life’s meaning through wisdom as a hard labor given by God.

questions.question: Which Old Testament book shares a similar theme of life's vanity as found in Ecclesiastes 1?
options: Job
Psalms
Proverbs
Isaiah
questions.correctAnswer: Job
questions.explanation: Both Job and Ecclesiastes wrestle with the themes of human suffering, the meaninglessness of life, and divine sovereignty.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage echoes the idea of 'no new thing under the sun' regarding human history?
options: 1 Corinthians 10:11
Revelation 21:5
John 1:1
Romans 8:28
questions.correctAnswer: 1 Corinthians 10:11
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 10:11 reflects on examples from history as warnings, echoing Ecclesiastes’ theme of repetition in human experience.

questions.question: How does the Preacher describe the rivers and the sea in Ecclesiastes 1?
options: Rivers run into the sea, but the sea is not full; they return to their source
Rivers dry up in the desert; the sea overflows
Rivers flow only once; the sea is still
Rivers are abundant; the sea is empty
questions.correctAnswer: Rivers run into the sea, but the sea is not full; they return to their source
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:7 describes the endless cycle of water, symbolizing the perpetual nature of natural processes.

questions.question: In the cultural context of ancient Near East, how might the Preacher's lament about vanity reflect Israel’s wisdom tradition?
options: It aligns with wisdom literature’s focus on human limitation and the quest for meaning
It rejects the law and prophets
It promotes idolatry as a solution
It contrasts with all wisdom traditions
questions.correctAnswer: It aligns with wisdom literature’s focus on human limitation and the quest for meaning
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes fits within the wisdom tradition, reflecting on human limitations and the search for purpose amidst life's brevity.

questions.question: What type of literary device is predominantly used in Ecclesiastes 1:8, 'The eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing'?
options: Parallelism
Chiasm
Metaphor
Allegory
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:8 uses synonymous parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device, to emphasize insatiable human desire.

theological.title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 1 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ecclesiastes Chapter 1 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: Who is identified as the author of Ecclesiastes Chapter 1?
options: The Preacher, the son of David, king in Jerusalem
Moses, the servant of God
The prophet Isaiah
King Solomon’s scribe
questions.correctAnswer: The Preacher, the son of David, king in Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:1 explicitly states that the words are of the Preacher, the son of David, king in Jerusalem, traditionally understood as Solomon. This aligns with Solomon's wisdom and royal authorship seen in 1 Kings 3:12 and Proverbs 1:1.

questions.question: What phrase does the Preacher use repeatedly to describe all human endeavors under the sun?
options: Vanity of vanities
Fruitless toil
Empty wind
Foolish labor
questions.correctAnswer: Vanity of vanities
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:2 uses the phrase 'Vanity of vanities; all is vanity' to emphasize the futility and emptiness of human effort apart from God. Similar themes appear in Psalm 39:5 and Isaiah 40:7-8, highlighting the transient nature of life.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 1:3, what is questioned regarding human labor?
options: What profit hath a man of all his labour which he taketh under the sun?
How long shall a man endure his toil?
Who receives the fruit of a man’s work?
Is labor the path to wisdom?
questions.correctAnswer: What profit hath a man of all his labour which he taketh under the sun?
questions.explanation: The Preacher questions the ultimate profit or gain from human labor in Ecclesiastes 1:3, challenging the meaning of work without eternal perspective. This reflects themes in Colossians 3:23-24 and Matthew 6:19-21 about eternal rewards.

questions.question: What does the Preacher observe about the generations and the earth in Ecclesiastes 1:4?
options: One generation passes away, another comes, but the earth abides forever
Generations flourish and fade with the seasons
The earth changes as generations rise and fall
Generations are forgotten but the earth is renewed
questions.correctAnswer: One generation passes away, another comes, but the earth abides forever
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:4 contrasts the transient nature of human generations with the enduring permanence of the earth, highlighting human mortality versus God’s creation’s stability, consistent with Psalm 102:25-27 and Hebrews 1:10-12.

questions.question: What cyclical natural phenomena does the Preacher describe to illustrate repetitive patterns?
options: The rising and setting of the sun, the turning of the wind, and rivers flowing to the sea
The changing of the seasons and the phases of the moon
The growth of plants and the migration of birds
The waxing and waning of stars
questions.correctAnswer: The rising and setting of the sun, the turning of the wind, and rivers flowing to the sea
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:5-7 describes the sun’s cycle, the wind’s circuit, and the rivers running into the sea but the sea never being full, illustrating the repetitive and unending cycles in nature, symbolizing human toil’s futility. Similar imagery is found in Psalm 19:4-6 and Jeremiah 51:13.

questions.question: What is said about human satisfaction with seeing and hearing in Ecclesiastes 1:8?
options: The eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing
The heart longs for peace beyond sensory experience
Man grows weary of what he sees and hears
Seeing and hearing bring complete knowledge
questions.correctAnswer: The eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:8 reveals the insatiable nature of human desire and perception, indicating that sensory experience alone cannot satisfy the soul. This aligns with Jeremiah 2:13 and Isaiah 55:1-2, which speak of thirst and hunger beyond physical senses.

questions.question: What theological truth about novelty and human experience is stated in Ecclesiastes 1:9?
options: There is no new thing under the sun
All things are new to each generation
God creates new things continually
Life is full of unprecedented events
questions.correctAnswer: There is no new thing under the sun
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:9 asserts the repetitiveness of human history and experience, emphasizing the cyclical nature of human affairs. This resonates with Psalm 90:4 and Romans 8:20, which reflect on the repetitive and groaning nature of creation.

questions.question: What does the Preacher say about the remembrance of former things and future things in Ecclesiastes 1:11?
options: There is no remembrance of former things; neither shall there be any remembrance of things to come
Former things are remembered, but future things are forgotten
Only God remembers the past and the future
The wise remember the past and anticipate the future
questions.correctAnswer: There is no remembrance of former things; neither shall there be any remembrance of things to come
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:11 highlights human forgetfulness of past events and the uncertainty about future events, underscoring human limitation apart from divine revelation. This is consistent with Isaiah 46:9-10 and Hebrews 8:12 regarding God's remembrance and forgiveness.

questions.question: What motivation does the Preacher give for seeking wisdom in Ecclesiastes 1:13?
options: To seek and search out by wisdom all things done under heaven
To gain riches and honor
To escape the vanity of life
To become greater than kings before him
questions.correctAnswer: To seek and search out by wisdom all things done under heaven
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:13 shows the Preacher’s pursuit of wisdom to understand life’s meaning, acknowledging it as a divine burden or travail given to humanity. Proverbs 2:6 and James 1:5 also emphasize the gift and pursuit of wisdom from God.

questions.question: How does the Preacher describe the outcome of his observation of all works under the sun in Ecclesiastes 1:14?
options: All is vanity and vexation of spirit
All is meaningful and joyful
Works bring lasting satisfaction
Labor leads to eternal reward
questions.correctAnswer: All is vanity and vexation of spirit
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:14 expresses the conclusion that human efforts without God’s purpose are empty and cause frustration, echoing themes of futility seen in Romans 8:20-22 and Psalm 73:16-17.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 1:15 say about the nature of crooked and wanting things?
options: That which is crooked cannot be made straight; and that which is wanting cannot be numbered
All things can be corrected by wisdom
Imperfections are temporary and fixable
God will make all things perfect in time
questions.correctAnswer: That which is crooked cannot be made straight; and that which is wanting cannot be numbered
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:15 teaches the limits of human ability to rectify certain realities, symbolizing the imperfect and incomplete nature of the world. This aligns with Romans 7:18-25 and Isaiah 64:6, acknowledging human fallenness.

questions.question: What realization does the Preacher come to about wisdom and knowledge in Ecclesiastes 1:18?
options: In much wisdom is much grief; and he that increaseth knowledge increaseth sorrow
Wisdom always brings joy and peace
Knowledge guarantees freedom from sorrow
Greater knowledge leads to greater happiness
questions.correctAnswer: In much wisdom is much grief; and he that increaseth knowledge increaseth sorrow
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:18 acknowledges that increased wisdom and knowledge can lead to greater sorrow, recognizing the burden of understanding a fallen world. This is consistent with Job 12:12 and 1 Corinthians 1:18-25 on the paradox of wisdom.

questions.question: How does the Preacher describe his personal status in Ecclesiastes 1:16?
options: I have come to great estate and gotten more wisdom than all before me in Jerusalem
I am a humble servant without much wisdom
I have forsaken wisdom for pleasure
I have inherited wisdom but lack understanding
questions.correctAnswer: I have come to great estate and gotten more wisdom than all before me in Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:16 describes the Preacher’s recognition of his superior wisdom and experience compared to previous generations, reflecting Solomon’s renowned wisdom in 1 Kings 4:29-34 and Proverbs 1:20-33.

questions.question: What does the Preacher say about the labor and toil of all things in Ecclesiastes 1:8?
options: All things are full of labour; man cannot utter it
Man’s labor can be fully expressed and understood
Labor is limited to human endeavor
Only the righteous experience toil
questions.correctAnswer: All things are full of labour; man cannot utter it
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:8 highlights the overwhelming and inexpressible nature of labor and toil in the world, echoing Genesis 3:17-19 and Romans 8:22-23 about the curse and frustration of creation.

questions.question: What does the Preacher declare about the sun in Ecclesiastes 1:5?
options: The sun also ariseth, and goeth down, and hasteth to his place where he arose
The sun stands still for the righteous
The sun governs the seasons
The sun is a symbol of God’s glory
questions.correctAnswer: The sun also ariseth, and goeth down, and hasteth to his place where he arose
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 1:5 describes the sun’s daily rising and setting as a metaphor for the repetitive cycles of life and nature, emphasizing the temporal and recurring pattern of creation, as seen also in Psalm 19:4-6 and Joshua 10:12-13.
